title: For an advanced piano player, if I have $10,000, should I buy a digital piano or an acoustic piano? - Quora

response.answer_text: There are a whole lot of considerations, and if you are an advanced piano player you know more than we do about how you prioritize things. There are some things acoustic pianos can do better than digital pianos, soundwise, although even that can be argued. (*) There are a HUGE number of things a digital piano can do that an acoustic simply can’t. From playing with headphones, to changing the instrument sound to recording MIDI (and possibly tweaking the performance after the fact), to putting it in your car to take to a gig or rehearsal or audition. I personally wouldn’t recommend spending all $10,000 now. Remember that digital equipment becomes outdated as newer better stuff comes along. You can get a MIDI controller and a nice computer, and upgrade parts of it in 5 or 10 years or whenever you want. Even spending $5k, you could have something like this, which is incredibly powerful compared to an acoustic piano.  * note that many times when you see a performer playing piano on stage, it is really a digital piano with an acoustic-looking cabinet. And if you are recording, a digital piano might sound better because you don’t have to bother with mic’ing it….you can just have it send MIDI to your computer, and record it using a VST. If you are recording using a computer with a physically modeled synthetic piano sound, I seriously doubt many people can tell the difference between it and a real acoustic piano. Listen at https://www.pianoteq.com/modeld

You can buy one heck of an outstanding new Samick acoustic grand ( discounted to $12,000 +/- for 5′4″ and 5′7″ ). For an advanced player a digital is completely out of the question. I had a Yamaha Clavinova and then an old Yamaha C3 while in grad school in 1993. I think I would have preferred a new Samick. I'd splurge just a little and avoid the digital. Shop carefully and patiently. In addition to teaching, I sold pianos for a number of years. It's a cutthroat business. Look for a 20% discount, or say you're ready to walk. Look for a showroom instrument the dealer is desperate to move. He won't tell you. A used Samick or Yamaha carefully evaluated by a technician should be available somewhere. Ken S Madell

As an advanced pianist, you’d ideally want to get a good grand piano. An upright or a cheap grand won’t cut it. Although a good, new grand piano is more than $10k, I’d imagine you can find a good used piano at that price. I personally use a digital piano and I love it. However, it’s definitely not the same as a grand piano. The dynamic range is less, the key mechanism is not quite the same (not necessarily better or worse, but it’s different from an acoustic—and different among the brands of digitals), and not all nuances of pedaling are modeled. If I were a professional, it wouldn’t be an acceptable substitute for an acoustic piano. However, I think the advantages are worth it for me: $2000 can buy a really good digital pianoSound is surprisingly realisticMake high-quality recordings easily: no expensive mic or studio neededCan use headphones to practice without bothering neighborsNo tuning or maintenance, less sensitive to temperature and humidityUsually comes with lots of instrument sounds (including different varieties of pianos, if you want a darker or brighter sound for different pieces) and other features (metronome, transpose, tunings, recording/playback stuff, etc)Reasonably portable: you don’t need to hire special movers for itYou can visit a music store and try their digital pianos. This will probably be the most useful thing you can do to help with your decision!

It depends what kind of place you live. Having a $10,000 piano, but never being able to play it due to noise complaints from neighbors makes it useless. If you’re going to be able to play it whenever you want — acoustic is great. Likewise, if you’re like me, and stay up and practice all night, but have other people in the house, the argument for a hybrid is strong. On the other hand, if you’re going to be using it to record, or teaching high level classical students, some people aren’t going to be so keen on a digital. That said, you don’t necessarily need to spend anywhere near that amount for a great digital. There are incredible hybrids in the low thousands.

$10 000 could get you a very good upright, a nice second-hand grand, or a lower-end new grand piano. If other considerations allow (like space, need for regular maintenance and people around that would force you to play with headphones), I would prefer acoustic. Especially for an advanced player. For digital, $10 000 is quite an overkill, in the $2 000 - 4 000 range the digitals are so good that I can’t see who would need anything more expensive.

Before you make up your mind, see if you can play the Galaxy Vintage D VST instrument, running on a pc or preferably a mac. It has been a revelation to me - better than most built in piano sounds and up there with a *very* good acoustic. At least, through headphones (if you want to amplify too, then that's another can of worms)

I would look around for one of the great old pianos in good condition. By good condition I mean, the action is pleasant to play, and it holds a tuning well. Don’t worry about the case; it’s nice to have a beautiful case, but it really doesn’t contribute to the sound. Also, the piano will have been played a lot, and the hammers could be very worn down. This makes for a tinny sound. Among the pianos I would look for would be: a Mason Hamlin AA (6′4″), or a Stieff, an A.B. Chase, or Conover, and the like. Replace the hammers. Have this work be done by a real artist-craftsman. I think you would be more than pleased!

You can get hybrids, that work like acoustics but you can plug headphones an and they become digital. Never actually used one myself but heard they’re good and sound pretty practical for home use if you’re worried about noise
